Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Impact of Vitamin Supplementation on Cardiovascular Health

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either vitamin supplementation or a placebo.

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included adults with a history of cardiovascular risk factors. Participants were recruited from a cardiovascular clinic.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received a combination of hydrophilic and lipophilic vitamins, while the control group received a placebo.

Objective.evidence: To evaluate the efficacy of vitamin supplementation in preventing CVD.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of cardiovascular events over a 12-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in cardiovascular events (mean difference = 5.2 events, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing gastrointestinal side-effects.
